HTML5 standard:
Work began in 2003 
 Working Draft as of 2011
HTML web browser features: N/A
Adobe Flash features:
Work began in 1996 
 Version 1 released in 1997

HTML web browser features: AmigaOS, MorphOS, Microsoft Windows, Apple Mac OS X, Linux
Adobe Flash features:
Microsoft Windows, Apple Mac OS X, 
 Linux (PPAPI-only after 11.2), Solaris

HTML web browser features: Windows Phone 8+, Android 2.3+, Apple iOS 6+, Symbian Belle+, BlackBerry OS 7+
Adobe Flash features: Up to Android 4.0 (unofficially for Android 4.1 and above), BlackBerry PlayBook, BlackBerry 10 v10.0 - 10.3.0 (10.3.1 unofficially supported), Windows RT

HTML web browser features: Xbox 360, Sony PlayStation 3, Nintendo Wii
Adobe Flash features: Sony PlayStation 3 (Flash 9 only), Nintendo Wii (Flash Lite only)

HTML web browser features: Limited access to web camera, microphone, accelerometer, GPS
Adobe Flash features: Full access to web camera, microphone, accelerometer, GPS

HTML web browser features:
~96% of internet connected PCs are CSS 2/3 ACID compliant,
 ~99% support JavaScript 1.5 or above, ~91% of devices support basic SVG
Adobe Flash features:
~95% of internet connected PCs
(~83% have Flash Player 11, ~17% have 10 and below)

HTML web browser features: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) supported on ~91% of browsers
Adobe Flash features: SWF with embedded graphics

HTML web browser features: Varying support of Filters in CSS3 (e.g. Glow, Blur, Drop Shadow, Sepia)
Adobe Flash features: Yes, applied to text or graphics (e.g. Glow, Drop Shadow, Bevel)

HTML web browser features: Yes
Adobe Flash features: Yes, with Saffron Type System

HTML web browser features: Installed fonts and custom fonts using CSS 3 web fonts
Adobe Flash features: Installed fonts and embedded fonts

HTML web browser features: Yes, implemented in most browsers, for system and custom fonts
Only supported inside "pre" tags
Adobe Flash features: Yes, with Text Layout Framework

HTML web browser features: Yes, using the "div" tag and CSS styling
Adobe Flash features: No, but text fields can be resized in ActionScript

HTML web browser features: Yes, using the "table" tag
Adobe Flash features: No, but text fields can be arranged into a grid

HTML web browser features: No
Adobe Flash features: Yes, with Text Layout Framework

HTML web browser features: JavaScript
Adobe Flash features: ActionScript, Pixel Bender

HTML5 standard: Cross-compiling of C++ code to JavaScript using Emscripten
HTML web browser features: Native code execution with Google Native Client in Google Chrome only
Adobe Flash features: Cross-compiling of C++ code to run in Flash Player using FlasCC

HTML web browser features: Plaintext JavaScript with limited obfuscation
Adobe Flash features: Compiled bytecode, can be obfuscated

HTML web browser features: CSS 3, HTML, XML, JSON
Adobe Flash features: JSON, XML, Subset of CSS 1

HTML web browser features: GZIP compression for HTML, JS and CSS files (on supported servers)
Adobe Flash features: LZMA or DEFLATE for SWF files

HTML web browser features: PNG, JPEG, Animated GIF
Adobe Flash features: PNG, JPEG, JPEG-XR, Single-frame GIF

HTML web browser features: Varying support of H.264, WebM and Ogg Theora (see HTML5 video)
Adobe Flash features: H.264, Sorenson Spark, and On2 VP6

HTML web browser features: Pseudo-streaming only of WebM and Ogg Theora using video tag
Adobe Flash features: Flash Video, H.264 and partial support for MP4

HTML web browser features: Varying support of MP3, Ogg Vorbis, WAV PCM, AAC and  WebM Vorbis (see HTML5 audio)
Adobe Flash features: MP3, WAV and AAC audio files or embedded sound

HTML web browser features: Supported on some browsers
Adobe Flash features: Yes, with warning displayed

HTML web browser features: No, all files being plaintext, except for obfuscation
Adobe Flash features: No, binary formatted files can be decompiled, this is merely obfuscation

HTML web browser features: Varying support of single file upload, and drag and drop of files onto browser
Adobe Flash features:
Support for single file upload and generation,
 AIR only: full create/read/write access to file system

HTML web browser features: Varying support for HTML5 "canvas" element
Adobe Flash features: Yes, using the BitmapData class

HTML web browser features: No, unless JavaScript Arrays are used for the same
Adobe Flash features: Yes, using the ByteArray class

HTML web browser features: Using Web Sockets to stream binary or XML data
Adobe Flash features: Yes, embedded or streaming binary data

HTML web browser features: Using Web storage or HTTP cookie to store binary or XML data
Adobe Flash features: Using Local Shared Object to store AMF-formatted data

HTML web browser features: Can be included in meta tag
Adobe Flash features: Extensible Metadata Platform
